text: Then Yuval would respond and say that AI doesn't need to have human like cognition to be able to be used to manipulate us (and he would give examples like how AI is being used currently to manipulate voters).

I'm wondering how important this feat is.
If allowing the AI to alter the reward function is to make any sense, there must be some sort of mechanism to determine which alterations are valuable and not.

One of the cold logics of the industrial age was that an educated workforce gave countries and their corporate masters a competitive advantage so companies weren't super angry at taxes going to schools.
I have predicted for awhile that open source AI will overtake closed source in very short order as the general public wouldn't have endless cash to fork over for software licenses.
That would force other parties to do the same if they want to compete, thus allowing unethical technology be forced upon everybody that doesn't want to be left behind on a global stage.
I put together a list of suggested places to start, both overview books and hands on resources.
If we've still got a chance, it seems to lay in open revolution against the last of our powers to shape our own society being turned over to algorithms.
